intro: Cryptopus elatus subsp. dissectus, commonly known as the dissected cryptopus, is a species of flowering plant native to southern Africa. It belongs to the family Ericaceae and is characterized by its distinctive, finely dissected leaves that give it a fern-like appearance. The plant produces small, bell-shaped flowers that are typically pink or white, which bloom in late spring to early summer. It thrives in well-drained, acidic soils and is often found in rocky or sandy habitats. Due to its ornamental value, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens, though it is not widely known outside of its native range.
